Hi Ken,

Thanks for your reply. I'm at the University of New South Wales, A=
ustralia
(same place I did my Honours project studying properties of HyperN=
EAT, with
same supervisor, Alan Blair). I look forward to sharing my ideas =
with you
and hopefully having your thoughts on them. :)
Do you think it wou=
ld be out of place for me to mention new blog posts on
the Yahoo group (if =
they are not explicitly about NEAT, HyperNEAT, etc)?

Cheers,
Oliver

rties of HyperNEAT for my Honours year a year or so ago). It's at

earch is about, but it also explains why I think the proposed

n evolving adaptive ANNs, which is clearly essential to the ultimate goals =

r>

ith a topic around neuroevolution, online-learning, adaptive NNs (via synap=
tic plasticity and/or similar). In my feverish excitement I thought it woul=
d be a good idea to start a blog on questions and issues I come across, in =
the hope that other active researchers will want to comment on and perhaps =
even start a bit of dialogue about them (like this mailing list but more pu=
blic). I know another Ph.D. candidate who keeps a similar blog (totally dif=
ferent research area, though) and it's working out great for her, so it=
 didn't seem like a completely hopeless idea...<br>

> <br>

now some of you are interested in the evolution of adaptive NNs, I read you=
r articles as soon as they were posted to this group! :) I also envisage us=
ing NEAT and variants in the research (I did a study of some of the propert=
ies of HyperNEAT for my Honours year a year or so ago). It's at <a href=
=3D"http://ojcoleman.com." target=3D"_blank">http://ojcoleman.com.</a> The =
first post is mostly background info (I hope I didn't get anything too =
wrong, let me know if you think I did!) and what the research is about, but=
 it also explains why I think the proposed approach is a good idea which mi=
ght provide some good controversy points (maybe not so much among this crow=
d, however).<br>
